intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: How dull. I don't sense any enemies nearby. I know! Would you all like me to tell you a story as we climb?

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: What kind of story?

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: One from long ago, long before the grandparents of anyone here were born.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: In the very beginning of this world...there was only water, until one day a girl appeared. The girl was very clever, and she forged the first land...then she made trees and flowers, and then she created beings.

intro.speaker: Tibarn
intro.line: The story of the grand creation? Heard it. Wake me when it's over.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: The girl was you, right, Yune? Or are you talking about Ashera?

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: Both, really...and neither, actually. At first, the girl was excited by her new world, and she thought of little else. Then she started feeling lonely. Everyone, every being she'd created, was different from her. Not a single person that could truly understand her. All alone, she grew sadder and sadder, crying for thousands of years. Then some creatures began to grow and change, becoming more clever and sophisticated. They tried to comfort the girl and eventually grew closer to her... That was the birth of the Zunanma. They were your ancestors...beorc, laguz, everyone.

intro.speaker: Sanaki
intro.line: In Begnion, we are taught that the Zunanma were human—Uhm, I mean...beorc ancestors... ...It makes me wonder what else in my country has been warped beyond recognition.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: It's possible that the truth was simply misunderstood. Like the way everyone calls me a dark god...

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: But let me continue... The Zunanma worshipped the girl as their own goddess. They said her hair was as striking a color as dawn's first light, so they gave her a name... The Goddess of Dawn. She was a much-loved goddess.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: The Goddess of Dawn...

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: The Zunanma continued to evolve and change, giving rise to a variety of races and tribes across the land. Naturally, each of the races thought their own was superior to the others, and conflict arose between them.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: The goddess tried to make peace among her people, but nothing could stop the warring Zunanma. Trying to separate the factions, the goddess gave them different names, laguz and beorc... But this only intensified their conflict.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: And then...the great flood occurred.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: The goddess was only trying to bring an end to the fighting. But her power was so great that all the continents were drowned in the flood, all except Tellius.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Are you sure about this story? It's very different from the histories that we've each been taught.

intro.speaker: Elincia
intro.line: Among beorc nations, we only know a vague fairy tale about the dark god stirring up a great disaster.

intro.speaker: Kurthnaga
intro.line: Neither the laguz nor the beorc have an accurate description by the sound of it. I wonder where the story got twisted.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: There is another standing in our way... I have a feeling he might be able to tell us.

intro.speaker: Kurthnaga
intro.line: ...Fa--...Father?

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Huh?

intro.speaker: Kurthnaga
intro.line: My father... Just beyond these doors, my father is waiting.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Dheginsea, king of Goldoa... He's supposed to be one of the three who defeated the dark god...Yune.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: He has been blessed by Ashera. Not only that, but it's a powerful, resilient blessing from long ago. He may be nearly impossible to defeat. ...Let's get everyone together. There's no better time than now.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: I was hoping to avoid this until we reached Ashera... Actually, I hoped not to have to do it at all... But she's left me with no choice. I will give you the blessings of Yune, goddess of chaos and freedom. In their natural state, the attacks of mortal creatures have no effect on divine beings.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: When Ashera set out to defeat me, she gathered her strongest warriors and bestowed on them some of her power. This is called the Goddess's Blessing... She empowered the dual swords of the beorc swordswoman, Altina. The laguz warrior, Soan, and Dheginsea, the leader of the dragon tribe, were also blessed.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: I failed then... But this time will be different. I'll use Ashera's own tricks, and I won't be defeated. Everyone... Take some time now to ready yourselves. Beorc, be sure to equip your best weapons. I'll begin when everyone's ready.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: I think we're all ready. I'll need the laguz to transform.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: Let's begin.

intro.speaker: Yune
intro.line: OK, I'm all done now. Whew... I... That was really hard... I think I... I think I need to rest.

intro.speaker: Sothe
intro.line: Micaiah? Are you feeling all right? You don't look so good.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: ...I'm fine. Thank you, Sothe.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: What happened to Yune?

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: She's sleeping. She wants us to take it from here.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: All right... If we're all set, let's move out.

intro.speaker: Kurthnaga
intro.line: Father!

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: Caineghis, the great lion king... How many times have I said it now? How many times have I warned against starting another war?

intro.speaker: Caineghis
intro.line: I know, old friend. I know...

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: Tibarn, the great hawk king... How many times have I said it now? How many times have I warned against starting another war?

intro.speaker: Tibarn
intro.line: Don’t you dare preach to me, you dried-up old fool.

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: Naesala, the great raven king... How many times have I said it now? How many times have I warned against starting another war?

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: And since when have I ever listened to the likes of you?

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: We have betrayed our vow to our goddess. We should have learned, but the fighting never stopped. Now we must pay for our crimes. We must take responsibility, and accept Ashera's judgment.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: No! You don't understand! It wasn't the war that awoke the goddess! It was my song... The galdr of release freed the goddess!

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: ...You can't expect me to believe that. We will wait here patiently for the punishment we deserve. If you are unwilling to await judgment...

intro.speaker: Dheginsea
intro.line: You will stand against... The greatest of all dragons!

intro.speaker: Kurthnaga
intro.line: Father, no! Why must we fight? There must be a way to talk this through.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: It's no use, Kurth. We have no choice but to fight. We must reach the goddess, and not even the king of dragons can stand in our way.

battle.speaker: Dheginsea
battle.line: Feel the power of Ashera's faithful!

battle.speaker: Dheginsea
battle.line: You have followed Yune's path here? That puts us irrevocably at odds. I'm sorry it had to be this way.

battle.speaker: Dheginsea
battle.line: You've declared war on a goddess... A foolish action with terrible consequences!

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: King Dheginsea, you are more powerful than any being alive... Use that power to help us save the people.

battle-talk.speaker: Dheginsea
battle-talk.line: You are not the first to make such a request. But my answer is the same now as it was before. I will not change my mind. I have no choice but to follow the will of our goddess.

battle-talk.speaker: Rafiel
battle-talk.line: King Dheginsea, I don’t understand... Why? Why must we fight? I just can’t... I... I... I can’t take it. Fighting only causes more pain and suffering. Why do this?

battle-talk.speaker: Dheginsea
battle-talk.line: ...You remind me of a friend from long ago. He was the kindest soul I’ve known, but he was so terribly weak. You’ve moved me more than you’ll ever know... But I will not budge. I await my judgment.

battle-talk.speaker: Dheginsea
battle-talk.line: Hello, Princess Leanne. You can’t fight me... I advise you to stand down.

battle-talk.speaker: Leanne
battle-talk.line: (Sadness... Your heart is filled with such sadness. What’s wrong? Can’t we talk about it?)

battle-talk.speaker: Dheginsea
battle-talk.line: I have nothing more to say to you. This is the way it has to be. My feelings do not matter.

recruit-battle.speaker: Gareth
recruit-battle.line: My prince... I was supposed to protect you, but... I failed.

recruit-battle.speaker: Kurthnaga
recruit-battle.line: No, Gareth! It was I that turned my back on Goldoa. Gareth... I'm sorry.

recruit-battle.speaker: Nasir
recruit-battle.line: I have lived long enough... Ena, I wish you...the best...

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Fools! By denying your judgment, you merely rush to your death.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: No... Unh... Has my body grown old? Or is it...my heart...

boss.speaker: Ena
boss.line: Your Majesty...

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Come now, Ena. Fight.

boss.speaker: Ena
boss.line: I'm sorry, I can't. I may have turned my back on my king and left my own country, but I still belong to the dragon tribe. I wouldn't dare attack my own king. I couldn't.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Then as your king, I order you. I order you to fight for Kurthnaga's life.

boss.speaker: Ena
boss.line: My king!

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You and he need each other. You are different from other dragons.

boss.speaker: Ena
boss.line: ...Very well, Your Majesty.

boss.speaker: Kurthnaga
boss.line: Father! Please think about what you're doing.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: The time for words has passed. The only option remaining is to stop you with brute force.

boss.speaker: Kurthnaga
boss.line: Why? Father, why?

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: That is enough! No more sniveling! You, Kurthnaga, were to rule the dragon tribe in years to come. Show me that you would have been capable!

boss.speaker: Kurthnaga
boss.line: But-- Yes, sir... I'll show you.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: In my eyes, the mightiest of you looks no different than an infant. Can you hope to stand a chance?

boss.speaker: Sanaki
boss.line: Of...of course. I am Sanaki, 37th empress of Begnion. It is my duty to save my people. Even the world's mightiest dragon will not dissuade me from that calling.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: All right, then, child. Fulfill your duty.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You, too, deign to oppose the goddess Ashera?

boss.speaker: Elincia
boss.line: I will do whatever is required to rescue those who were petrified. I beg of you, Dragon King, please reconsider what Prince Kurthnaga said to you.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: It is too late. People, in our weakness, betray the gods, and are meant to be punished for it.

boss.speaker: Elincia
boss.line: I cannot believe that. People are capable of both terrible and wonderful things. To describe them so simply and cynically does them a disservice.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: If I am defeated today, that may convince me that I am wrong. Come... I'm waiting.

boss.speaker: Tibarn
boss.line: I never would have believed that one day I'd be facing off against you. Life sure is funny, sometimes.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Even you, Tibarn? Don't make me kill you. You haven't got a chance.

boss.speaker: Tibarn
boss.line: Don't be so sure about that. You just might be surprised. Besides, you've got a lot to answer for, Dheginsea. You'll finally pay the price for all those years of inaction and indifference as your kin were butchered and enslaved.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You shortsighted fool, you still don't understand... All right, I'm waiting. Show me what you've got.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Have at you, follower of Yune.

boss.speaker: Sothe
boss.line: I won't live as long as you have, and I'll never be as powerful. Things like saving the world and fighting goddesses are just beyond me. They're out of my reach. That's why I've always chosen to fight for the smaller things in life and the people close to me. If that means I have to fight you to protect them, then so be it.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You...you're one of the parentless...

boss.speaker: Micaiah
boss.line: You know me?

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Yes. I knew the first of your kind. I have been alive for a very long time... Perhaps too long. But soon it will all be over.

boss.speaker: Ike
boss.line: Dheginsea, Dragon King. I can see you have no intention of letting us pass.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: I follow my goddess's decrees. My will is unwavering.

boss.speaker: Ike
boss.line: I have no choice, then. Be on your guard.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Very well, beorc general. Our blessings may be equal and opposite, but your strength is a mere fraction of mine. Show me your best!

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Naesala, you dare challenge me?

boss.speaker: Naesala
boss.line: Heh. It’s funny you should ask that... I’m not deluded enough to think that I can beat you. The goddess herself would hesitate to fight you. But my people are frozen solid, and I have to delude myself enough to think that I can help save them.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You are a true king, Naesala. I am ready when you are.

boss.speaker: Naesala
boss.line: I’ll be thrilled if I land even a single blow. I’m much better at fleeing than fighting.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: You... are of the wolf people?

boss.speaker: Nailah
boss.line: Yes. After the floods, we built our country to the east of the great desert.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: ...So we weren’t the only ones to survive...

boss.speaker: Nailah
boss.line: Until we met Rafiel, we too thought ours were the only people left.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: In your country, are there only people of the wolf tribe?

boss.speaker: Nailah
boss.line: No, beorc live there, as well. There are also a number of what you call the "parentless." Children born of both laguz and beorc parents are still relatively few.. but they live normally among us.

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: Is that so?

boss.speaker: Nailah
boss.line: That’s probably enough chatting. Do you still intend to block our path?

boss.speaker: Dheginsea
boss.line: ...I will not deny my goddess.

boss.speaker: Nailah
boss.line: And I won’t deny my conscience. I will revive those turned to stone, and you cannot stop me.

end.speaker: Dheginsea
end.line: My queen... Rajaion... I will soon join you.

end.speaker: Yune
end.line: It's happening again... Whose memory is that?! Something feels so...familiar about it. Is that... Is that your memory?

end.speaker: Kurthnaga
end.line: I know. This is simply another reason to move on... Entrusted by my father to care for our people, I will stand before Ashera. ...As the king of the dragon tribe!

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 1
flashback.line: We must save them. Even now, as we speak, countless laguz slaves endure Begnion chains. They suffer terribly.

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 2
flashback.line: We have done all that we will do.

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 1
flashback.line: Admonitions and censures change nothing! Now is the time for the dragon tribes to use their strength to save the oppressed laguz!

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 2
flashback.line: Goldoa does not interfere with the outside world. As king of dragons, I will not allow my people to fan the flames of war. Conflict on the scale you describe will wake the goddess and call down her judgment upon us all. This is the path to destruction. A thousand years... That is how long we swore to the goddess that there would be no war. Have you forgotten our covenant?

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 1
flashback.line: Of course not. Yet...there are laguz who are treated as less than livestock. I cannot believe that this is what the goddess wants.

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 2
flashback.line: Goldoa will not move. This decree stands from the time our nations were formed. The goddess has not yet slept one hundred and fifty years. Would you see the laguz and beorc destroyed? Would you see all of Tellius awash in blood? No, unless destruction comes to seek us at our door, Goldoa will not move, for the sake of future generations.

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 1
flashback.line: Tell me, do you care nothing for the laguz who suffer in the current generation? Do you think it would comfort them to know that you condone their misery?

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 1
flashback.line: To Begnion. I will find a solution without you.

flashback.speaker: Male Voice 2
flashback.line: You, who have lost your birthright? All you will accomplish is your own destruction. Hold...hold, I say!

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: Are you all right, Micaiah?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Yes, I’m fine. How about you, Sothe? Are you all right? You’re not hurt?

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: I’m not a child, Micaiah! When are you going to start treating me like an adult?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Show me your hand.

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: What?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Look at your hands. They’re so big... They were so small when we met.

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: Micaiah...

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Ahh... Sorry. Am I interrupting something?

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: C-Commander!

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: It’s all right, Ike. How can we help you?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: I was scrounging around in my stuff and found some extra medicine. I figured I’d ask around and see if anyone needed it.

conversation.speaker: Sothe
conversation.line: ...I need to go get ready.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hey, there’s no rush. We still have... He didn’t catch a word of that, did he?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: I’m sorry about that.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: How long have you been with him?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: ...A long time. I met him when I was hiding out in the back alleys of Nevassa, over ten years ago. He was so skinny, but his gaze was so piercing... I wondered how such a young boy could look like that. One day, I noticed he was standing close to me, just watching. He continued like that for a few days. One day, I held out my hand. He was suspicious of me, but came over anyway. He looked like a scared animal. Then his little hand slipped into mine. It was shaking. His fingers were so thin and frail. I couldn’t let go after that.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: After that, we traveled together all over the continent. No matter where we went, we were always together.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: The first time I met him, he’d hidden on a ship we were taking. He mentioned he was looking for someone who was like family to him. It was you he was searching for, wasn’t it?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: I...I tried to leave him behind. When we went to Crimea, I split off from him and took a ship to Begnion. But when I reached Begnion, war had broken out between Crimea and Daein. I knew I had to return to Daein to look for him. I couldn’t find him, so I went to Crimea. But I still couldn’t find him... We found each other again after the war, in Daein. In the back alleys of Nevassa, where we first met.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: You took routes opposite to each other.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: When I told him why I’d disappeared, he got so angry... I’d never seen him get so emotional before.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: I can’t say that I blame him. I’d be pretty furious if I heard someone that I loved was wandering around two countries at war. Besides, I’m sure he’d hidden his feelings about being abandoned until he saw you again.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: I thought I was reaching the limit of how long I could stay with him. He grew each and every day, but I remained the same... I didn’t want him to be harmed by the curse I lived with. Can you imagine how hard that would have been on him?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: You mean the blood of the laguz?

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: So you knew. Did you find out from the boy who’s always beside you?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Soren. Yeah. I guess you both know how to recognize people with a similar nature.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Yes. He and I are both Branded.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: ...Don’t use that word. You and Soren are both people. Just like me and everyone else.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: People. You’re just like Yune. You call both laguz and beorcs people.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Why should I care about the color of your hair, eyes, and skin? Or your ears, wings, or tail? No matter how long you live or what powers you possess, we’re the same. At the end of the day, we’re all people.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: ... Sothe talks that way, too. His time with you changed him. Thank you, Ike. I’ve made up my mind.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: About what? I didn’t realize we were doing anything but talking.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: I thought I might travel to a far-off place after all of this was over. But I won’t. I’ll go back to Daein. No matter what happens, I’ll have Sothe by my side. I have nothing to fear as long as he’s with me.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: It seems the feelings between you two run both ways. But that’s probably the wisest choice for Daein, and Sothe too. Anyway...

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Oh, um... May I have some medicine?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Oh! Yeah, I almost forgot. Survive, Micaiah. We need you, and the goddess you host, to save the people of Tellius.

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Yes. I know.

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: Zelgius is the Black Knight? I don’t know what to say... It’s unbelievable!

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: What was he like in Begnion?

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: He was the right-hand man of my most trusted aide, Duke Sephiran of Persis. He was a hero, a perfect general, and the best swordsman in all of Tellius. He was never anything but loyal. But he was serving another country!

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hmm. It makes me wonder how Sephiran is doing.

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: I doubt he’s been turned to stone. Even though he was captured by Lekain and forcibly removed from his post, he’ll have found a way to persevere. Sigrun always said there’s no other master of the arcane arts who can compare with the duke of Persis.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Makes you wonder, doesn’t it?

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: Ike... Don’t tell me you suspect Sephiran!

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Well, look at the facts...

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: Do not trouble your mind with that thought! He would never betray me.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: It’s nice to think so. But if he’s not petrified, he’d have received a message from Yune. So where is he?

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: The goddess isn’t perfect. She said so herself! Maybe the message didn’t reach everyone.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: ...You have to admit that’s a weak excuse. Let’s leave it at that, for now. We need to focus on moving forward.

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: Please, let’s! Oh, I almost forgot! I have something for you.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: What is it?

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: Um... Uh... Well, you’re my trusted aide, just like Sephiran. You have to live! So protect yourself with this.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: A mercenary with a contract to act as aide to the empress of Begnion. Who’d have thought? But thank you, Sanaki.

conversation.speaker: Sanaki
conversation.line: You’re welcome, Ike. And thank you.

conversation.speaker: Rafiel
conversation.line: Ike, take a look at this.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hey now... Where’d you stumble across it?

conversation.speaker: Rafiel
conversation.line: Inside the tower. I thought of using it myself, but...

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Yeah, I don’t think that it’s right for you.

conversation.speaker: Rafiel
conversation.line: ...Indeed. That’s why I brought it here for you to use.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Thanks. It’s a very rare item. I’m in your debt.

conversation.speaker: Rafiel
conversation.line: It’s the least I could do.

conversation.speaker: Reyson
conversation.line: Ike, take a look at this.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hey now... Where’d you stumble across it?

conversation.speaker: Reyson
conversation.line: Lying around inside the tower. It seemed like the sort of thing I should bring to your attention.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: That’s very nice of you, but you didn’t have to. Do whatever you want with it.

conversation.speaker: Reyson
conversation.line: Really? Do you think I’d be able to use it?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Well, don’t get hasty. I don’t think it’s right for you.

conversation.speaker: Reyson
conversation.line: ...I know. I’m just kidding, Ike.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Thanks. It’s a very rare item. I’ll cherish it.

conversation.speaker: Reyson
conversation.line: Please do.

conversation.speaker: Leanne
conversation.line: (Micaiah, have you ever seen one of these?)

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Yes, Leanne, I have. That’s a very powerful artifact. Actually, it would be of great help to us, with what’s been happening.

conversation.speaker: Leanne
conversation.line: (I found it inside the tower. Do you think I can use it?)

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Um... I don’t think so, Leanne. But you can try if you like...

conversation.speaker: Leanne
conversation.line: (...I’m only kidding. Here, you can have it.)

conversation.speaker: Micaiah
conversation.line: Oh, for me? Thank you very much. It’s a very precious item. I’ll make good use of it.

conversation.speaker: Leanne
conversation.line: (Please do!)
